about:
Reliability architect. I assemble, test, and document.
My field: clean infrastructures, lean deployments, solid systems.
aboutl:
I design system architectures focused on reliability, testability, and embedded documentation.
My journey spans system admin, tech prototyping, and software mediation.
I work with real constraints, not hype.
I dig into breaking points to craft stable, practical solutions.

projets.probleme: AI is everywhere, yet its inner workings remain opaque to most.
solution: Local, readable, modular base, structured by phases
Phase 1: minimal chatbot using FastAPI, local LLM via llama.cpp, and a Streamlit interface
Step-by-step scripts and documentation to serve as a teaching scaffold
Designed for future expansion: CI/CD, observability, model interchange, RAG, fine-tuning
apprentissage: Clarified the backend ↔ model ↔ interface interaction
Rebuilt a minimal CI mindset without cloud dependencies
Structured an extensible base under tight technical constraints
Public release with code, video, and slides: full delivery of a first project phase

projets.stack: Raspberry Pi Zero, Syncthing, Linux USB gadget
projets.probleme: Keeping data synced across PCs, spots, and platforms is a hassle: desktop, laptop, work rig...
solution: Active sync key backs up and versions files on the fly.
Plugs in as a standard USB or software key.
Wi-Fi sync with other keys via a physical button pair.
Raspberry Pi Zero with Debian, gadget mode for USB
Partitions for data, restore, and OS.
Syncthing handles the sync.
apprentissage: UX suffered without a front-end
Behavior flipped across PCs, even Windows—why?
Flawless on my dev box, a coin toss elsewhere.
Simple idea, daily curveballs
Had buyers, one paid up, others were keen
Got dev help, a friend chimed in on brainstorming.

Took way longer than planned but landed functional
